abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Background: In Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD), the literature on emotion awareness revealed some discrepancies between some patients who are accurate in detecting emotional cues and others that are impaired at identifying them in themselves and others.

Objective: Even though some links between childhood adversity and emotion regulation have been established, there is a need to understand the mechanisms underlying this association, and defense mechanisms, which are central to emotion regulation, and could play a key role in this pathway.

Method: The purpose of this study is to compare levels of emotional awareness between adolescents with BPD and healthy controls and to investigate the influence of adversity (maltreatment and parental bonding) and defense mechanisms influence on emotional awareness in the two groups, as measured by the Level of Emotional Awareness Scale (LEAS). The study includes BPD adolescents (n = 41) and healthy controls (HC, n = 67).

Results: No difference was observed between the LEAS in BPD and HC, but multivariate regression models analysed highlighted links between levels of emotional awareness and adversity: low levels of self-emotion awareness were associated with maltreatment and with maternal control, while high levels of emotional awareness were linked to low levels of maternal care.

Conclusions: In BPD, immature defense mechanisms mediated the association between maltreatment and self-emotional awareness, suggesting a key role of defense mechanisms in maintaining a normal level of emotional awareness in the face of adversity.

list-item.p: In this first study comparing levels of emotional awareness between adolescents with BPD and HC, no group differences were observed on emotion awareness scores (self or other).
In adolescents with BPD, maltreatment’s score was correlated with lower emotion awareness of self.

In adolescents with BPD, a lower level of maternal care was associated with higher levels of other’s emotional awareness, while a higher level of maternal control was associated with a lower levels of self and other’s emotional awareness.
The mediational analysis revealed that immature defense mechanisms have a protecting role by maintaining a normal level of self-emotional awareness in case of maltreatment in the BPD group.

trans-abstract.p: Antecedentes: En el Trastorno de Personalidad Limite (TPL), la literatura sobre la conciencia emocional reveló algunas discrepancias entre algunos pacientes que son precisos en detectar señales emocionales y otros que tienen problemas en identificarlas en sí mismos y en los demás.

Objetivo: Pese a que se han establecido algunos vínculos entre la adversidad infantil y la regulación emocional, es necesario comprender los mecanismos subyacentes a esta asociación, y los mecanismos de defensa, que son centrales para la regulación emocional, podrían desempeñar un papel importante en esta vía.

Método: El propósito de este estudio es comparar los niveles de conciencia emocional entre los adolescentes con TPL y controles sanos e investigar la influencia de la adversidad (maltrato y vinculo parental) y de los mecanismos de defensa en la conciencia emocional en ambos grupos, medida mediante la Escala de Nivel de Conciencia Emocional (LEAS por sus siglas en ingles). Este estudio incluye adolescentes TPL (n = 41) y controles sanos (CS, n = 67).

Resultados: No se observaron diferencias entre la LEAS en TPL y CS, pero los modelos de regresión multivariados analizados destacaron vínculos entre los niveles de conciencia emocional y adversidad: los niveles bajos de conciencia de las propias emociones se asociaron con maltrato y con el control materno, mientras que los niveles altos de conciencia emocional se vincularon con niveles bajos de cuidado materno.

Conclusiones: En TPL, los mecanismos de defensa inmaduros mediaron la asociación entre el maltrato y la conciencia de las propias emociones, lo que sugiere un papel clave de los mecanismos de defensa en el mantenimiento de un nivel normal de conciencia emocional frente a la adversidad.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Borderline personality disorder (BPD), which affects approximately 15% of adolescents in the general population and 50% of hospitalized patients (Becker et al., 2002), is characterized by emotional dysregulation as a core feature and severe difficulties in interpersonal functioning (Linehan, 1993). The difficulty in modulating emotional responding appears central to the development of serious behavioral difficulties including impulsive and self-destructive behaviors (Chapman, 2019). Emotional awareness is one of the several processes involved in the emotion regulation system (McMain et al., 2013), described by Lane & Schwartz as a cognitive skill reflecting ability to identify, label, describe, and understand emotions in oneself and others (Lane et al., 1990; Lane & Smitth, 2021). Clinical theories consider that a lack of mentalization and emotional awareness is observed in patients with BPD (Cole et al., 2009; Fonagy & Luyten, 2009), and that BPD emotional dysregulation is linked to the subjects’ difficulty in identifying emotional stimuli (Linehan, 1993). However, studies show contradictory results. A meta-analysis of 39 studies, highlighted a moderate association between emotional awareness and BPD (Derks et al., 2017). In the field of mentalization, which is a close concept to emotional awareness, studies showed that patients with BPD have lower mentalization than controls, whereas other studies observed higher mentalization abilities than in controls (Sharp & Vanwoerden, 2015; Janczak, 2018; McLaren et al., 2022). The Level of Emotional Awareness Scale (LEAS) is a tool for assessing awareness of one's emotions and the emotions of others. It is based on a developmental theory developed by Lane & Schwartz based on five stages ranging from the sensorimotor reflex stage to the formal operant stage (Lane et al., 1990). In this perspective, the development of emotions is inseparable from the development of the self and the relationship with others. The LEAS has been used with subjects with BPD in only one study, in which Levine et al. (1997) observed a lower level of emotional awareness in adult subjects with BPD compared to healthy controls.

Developmental theories focus on early interactions to explain the development of emotional ability processes. The child learns through the affective reactions of their attachment figure, not only to understand emotions expressed in their relational environment but also to understand their own emotionality, through the mirroring function (Brun, 2015; Miljkovitch & Ensink, 2022; Winnicott et al., 1975). Thus, inadequate early interactions can impair emotional awareness process and emotion regulation (Ensink et al., 2017). Childhood maltreatment has been well established in the literature as an important risk factor for BPD in adults and adolescents (Winsper et al., 2016), but few studies have explored the interrelationships between childhood adversity and emotional regulation or emotional awareness in BPD. Experimentally, Brüne et al. (2016) found that mentalizing was inversely correlated with maternal overprotection, lack of emotional availability, rejection, punishment and parental separation at an early developmental age in a population of thirty subjects with BPD. In a sample of students from the general population, Smith et al. (2023) described that lower emotional awareness was correlated with early adversity (parental abuse/neglect). However to date, no study has investigated the correlation between childhood adversity and emotional awareness measured by the LEAS in BPD subjects.

Defense mechanisms are defined as unconscious mechanisms that mediate the individual’s reaction to emotional conflicts or external situations arising from difficulties in adapting inner needs, impulses, desires and thoughts to the real world (American Psychiatric Association, 2013). They serve to eliminate or attenuate negative sensations connected to dangerous threatening events or emotional experiences, real or imaginary (Olson et al., 2011). Mature defense mechanisms are associated with psychological health and better emotional and behavioral adjustment (Martino et al., 2020), whereas immature defense mechanisms are associated with various levels of severity of psychological functioning and different psychopathological conditions, especially personality disorders (Perry et al., 2013). In a classic article on BPD organization, Kernberg suggests that splitting, primitive idealization, projection (projective identification), omnipotence, devaluation and denial were specific defenses used by patients with BPD (Kernberg, 1967). Following this description, several studies attempted to characterize BPD defense mechanisms, and confirmed the higher prevalence of immature defense mechanisms in BPD compared to other diagnoses (Zanarini et al., 2009). But to our knowledge, no study has investigated the relationship between emotional awareness and defense mechanisms in BPD, whereas emotion awareness reflects the ability to identify these emotions that defense mechanisms regulate.

The objective of this study was to investigate the respective influence of childhood adversity experiences and defense mechanisms on emotional awareness measured with the LEAS, with the hypothesis that defense mechanisms mediate the effect of adversity on BPD emotional awareness.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The study population was composed of 41 BPD adolescents (87% female), with a mean age of 16.5 years (sd = 1.4), and 67 healthy controls. The sample was drawn from a European network investigating BPD in adolescence (European Research Network on Borderline Personality Disorder, EURNET BPD), which aimed to investigate psychopathology of BPD in adolescence in 85 adolescents with this diagnosis and 84 healthy controls (Corcos et al., 2013). All subjects completed a research protocol, consisting of a diagnostic evaluation of Axis I and Axis II disorders, and a self-administered questionnaire to collect socio-demographic and psychopathological data, including emotional functioning, childhood traumas, parental bonding, and defense mechanisms. The LEAS was proposed only to the first 41 patients and the first 67 controls included, in order to maintain the feasibility of the study for the whole sample, given the length of time it took to fill in the tool (about 45 min), which extended the inclusion time with patients facing cognitive and behavioral instability.

Borderline patients were recruited in five adolescent-specialized academic psychiatry departments in France, Belgium, and Switzerland. Patients aged 13–19 were considered for inclusion if they presented BPD symptoms according to their psychiatrist. BPD diagnosis was confirmed by a semi-structured interview (Structured Interview for DSM Personality disorders, SIDP-IV; Pfohl et al., 1997). Participants in the control group, individually matched for gender and age, were recruited via an advertisement for the study placed in schools and universities of the same geographical areas. The procedure with this non-clinical sample was identical. HC were excluded if they had a diagnosis of current or lifetime mental disorder. A national institutional review board approved the study and a written informed consent was obtained from adolescents and parents (authorization n◦ 0611259).

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: The level of cognitive-emotional development was assessed with the LEAS (Lane et al., 1990). This self-questionnaire includes twenty evocative interpersonal situations and each scene involves two persons. The scenes are constructed to elicit four types of emotion (anger, fear, happiness, and sadness), at five levels of increasing complexity. Each scene is followed by two questions: ‘How would you feel?’ and ‘How would the other person feel?’ Subjects are asked to write their responses to both questions. The responses are scored using specific structural criteria. Each scene receives separate scores ranging from 0 to 4 for the emotion described for self and for other. The total score for each scene represents the higher of the self and other focused scores. As the original version, the French version of the LEAS revealed satisfactory psychometric criteria (Cronbach alpha = 0.75, inter-rater agreement kappa = 0.963 (0.921–0.982)) (Bydlowski et al., 2002). In this study, scales were rated by S.B. and M.R. with an inter-rater agreement of kappa = 0.961 (0.912–0.986), according to specific structural criteria (see Lane et al. (1990) for a detailed description of the scoring procedure). Each scene receives separate scores for the emotion described for self and for other. In addition, a total score is given for each scene.

The assessment of childhood maltreatment was performed using the Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ; Bernstein et al., 1994). It is a 28 items self-report instrument which retrospectively assesses five areas of maltreatment experiences during childhood (sexual abuse, physical abuse, physical neglect, emotional abuse and emotional neglect). Each item is rated on a five-point Likert scale (1 – never true to 5 – very often true). The total score of all items was used to determine the severity of each participant’s overall experience of childhood maltreatment. The French CTQ version showed internal consistency coefficients similar to the original version (α from .79 to .94), and confirmatory factor analyses replicated the original five-factor structure (Paquette et al., 2004).

The Parental Bonding Instrument (PBI) is a self-administered questionnaire, which is widely used to measure the subjective experience of parent–child bonding, from the child’s point of view (Parker et al., 1979). It has 12 ‘care' and 13 ‘control' items, each one being scored on a 4-point Likert scale. These items are used to generate Care and Control scores for each parent, ranging from 0 to 36 for Care and 0 to 39 for Control. The French version of the PBI revealed a high structural validity and comparable psychometric properties to the original version, as well as a similarity between the structural pattern for mothers and fathers (Mohr et al., 1999).

The defense mechanisms were evaluated with the Defense Style Questionnaire (DSQ) (Vaillant et al., 1986), which is a 9-point Likert scale that measures the conscious derivatives of different defense mechanisms through 88 items. The defense score is the average response of items contributing to the specific set. A higher score indicates greater use of the respective defense mechanism. According to Andrews et al. (1989) a factor analysis has identified 25 separate defenses that cluster into three higher order defense styles by their functional adequacy: mature, neurotic and immature. The French version of the DSQ showed psychometric similar properties to the original version, with a grouping of defense mechanisms, ranging from mature to an immature hierarchy (Bonsack et al., 1998).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All variables, including emotional functioning (LEAS scores), childhood adversity (CTQ and PBI scores), and defense mechanisms (DSQ scores), were compared between the BPD and HC groups. For continuous variables, mean scores were compared using either t-tests or Wilcoxon rank-sum tests, depending on the normality of the data, which was assessed prior to analysis. Effect sizes were calculated for all comparisons, with Cohen's d for t-tests and rank-biserial correlations for non-parametric tests, to provide a clear measure of the magnitude of differences. We applied the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure to control the False Discovery Rate (FDR), ensuring a balance between Type I error control and statistical power in the presence of multiple comparisons. Multivariate regression models were constructed separately for the BPD and HC groups to predict emotional awareness (LEAS scores), ensuring that appropriate assumptions for these models were met. Additionally, we investigated the mediating role of defense mechanisms (DSQ_Immature) in the relationship between maltreatment (CTQ_total as independent variable) and emotional awareness (LEAS-Self as dependent variable). Mediation analysis was performed using non-parametric bootstrap confidence intervals with the percentile method, ensuring robust estimates regardless of distributional assumptions. These approaches ensured the use of proper statistical tests and the presentation of meaningful effect sizes for all analyses. We used R 4.4.2 and several R packages for data processing, statistical analysis, and results formatting.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The comparison between BPD (n = 41) and HC (n = 67) revealed no significant differences in LEAS scores, indicating similar levels of emotional awareness (p > .05), effect sizes ranging from small to negligible: Cohen’s d = −0.107 to −0.269). However, adolescents with BPD reported significantly higher scores on the Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ), reflecting greater exposure to adverse childhood experiences, with a medium effect size (r = −0.502). Regarding parental bonding, BPD participants scored lower on paternal care (PBI_paternal care, p < .001, r = 0.552, medium to large effect sizes) and higher on controlling attitudes from both parents (PBI_maternal control, p < .05, r = −0.231, PBI _paternal control p < .05, r = −0,335, small to medium effect sizes).

Additionally, BPD exhibited markedly higher scores for neurotic (d = 1.026, large effect size) and immature defense mechanisms (d = 0.921, large effect size). In contrast, mature defenses showed no significant difference (p = .438, d = 0.162, small effect size) (Table 1). Table 1.

There was no significant relationship between emotional awareness of others and defense mechanisms in the BPD group (Model 3b). However, when considering parental bonding and defense mechanisms (Models 4b, 5b, 6b), maternal control was negatively associated with all three LEAS scores, including total emotional awareness (β = −0.45, p < .01) and self-awareness (β = −0.45, p < .01) in Models 5b and 6b, respectively. Furthermore, maternal care was inversely correlated with emotional awareness of others (β = −0.45, p < .05) in Model 6b.

The Average Causal Mediation Effect (ACME), representing the indirect effect of maltreatment (CTQ_total) on self-emotional awareness (Leas_self) through the immature defense mechanism mediator (DSQ_immature), was estimated at 0.049 (Figure 1). This implies that an increase of 10 points in the CTQ_total score is associated with an average increase of 0.4 points in LEAS_self. The effect was statistically significant (p = .046, 95% C.I. [0.00185, 0.12]). This indicates that the mediator of immature defense mechanisms significantly transmits the effect of maltreatment on self-emotional awareness. The Average Direct Effect (ADE), reflecting the direct influence of maltreatment on self-emotional awareness independent of immature defense mechanisms, was estimated at −0.106 (p = .048, 95% C.I. [−0.246, 0.00]). This suggests that maltreatment score has a substantial direct negative effect on self-emotional awareness. The Total Effect, which combines both direct and indirect effects, was estimated −0.057 (p = .248, 95% C.I. [−0.174, 0.03]), and was not statistically significant (p = .248). This implies that the overall impact of maltreatment on self-emotional awareness is not statistically discernible within the given sample, and that the influence of maltreatment on self-emotional awareness is transmitted both directly and indirectly through the mediator of immature defense mechanisms. The immature defense mechanisms thus appear to partially buffer the deleterious effects of childhood adversity on emotional self-awareness. Figure 1.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The aim of our study was to explore levels of emotional awareness in adolescents with BPD and to investigate their link with adversity and defense mechanisms within this population. In line with our hypothesis, it was possible to reveal distinct links between adversity types and emotional awareness. Moreover, we observed a mediational effect of defense mechanisms on BPD emotional awareness. First, we observed preserved levels of emotional awareness among adolescents with BPD compared with HC. Previous findings on emotional awareness in patients with BPD remain contradictory (Jańczak, 2018). In a meta-analysis on mentalization including 39 studies, a moderate association was found between low levels of emotional awareness and BPD (Derks et al., 2017). In this study, the authors discuss these findings in light of the continuity between borderline psychopathology, negative affectivity and alexithymia. When negative affectivity was controlled for, a significant number of studies no longer observed a correlation with alexithymia in their samples. Furthermore, all the studies used self-questionnaires for emotional awareness and borderline diagnosis. Alexithymia was measured with the TAS-20, which is a self-questionnaire that assesses the subject's perception of his/her emotional awareness. In contrast, the LEAS requires external raters to analyse the subject's responses in social situations, making it a more objective measure of emotional awareness compared to the TAS-20 (Lane et al., 1998). In this context, the authors point out the paradox of exploring emotions and disorder through self-awareness in subjects who show a deficit in these abilities. Finally, unlike the TAS, which is widely used in the studies listed in the meta-analysis, the LEAS showed much clearer independence from negative affectivity. In contrast to our study, the diagnoses measures were also based on hetero-assessments. Our study, by avoiding self-report bias, provides direct evaluation of patient’s diagnoses, and of emotional awareness, which is not altered, and not on their judgment on their emotional perception, which is often depreciative (Loas et al., 2012). It also allows a more complex understanding of emotional awareness, by highlighting determining factors that have distinct and sometimes contradictory effects (controlling and lack of caring attitudes). The age of the participants in our study could thus suggest that the deficits observed in the adult studies are not yet visible at the onset of the disorders.

This research allowed us to explore factors that may influence the level of emotional awareness beyond the diagnosis of BPD. In fact, diagnoses have been relevant for drawing differences in levels of emotional awareness between psychiatric disorders. For example, LEAS scores have been described as increased in anxiety disorder and decreased in eating disorders, compared to healthy control groups (Bydlowski et al., 2005; Novick-Kline et al., 2005). But the heterogeneity in emotional perception and regulation observed in the literature data on BPD calls for a more detailed exploration of the underlying phenomena that may be involved. For example, the mixed results produced by studies on facial emotion included the description of lower, unchanged or enhanced capacities in patients with BPD compared to healthy controls (Berenson et al., 2018; Frick et al., 2012; Mitchell et al., 2014; Vestergaard et al., 2020). Different hypotheses have been envisaged to explain this discrepancy, but the history and the nature of adversity in childhood are particularly envisaged as strong factors of influence (Kay & Green, 2016; Robin et al., 2022). In our study, maltreatment was associated to low levels of emotional awareness of self, whereas low maternal care was associated to hypersensitivity of other’s emotions and maternal overcontrol with low emotional awareness of self and others. Our results pursue those of the literature in the sense of suggesting that the heterogeneity of emotional perception mechanisms in patients with BPD could be explained by the diversity of the effects of adversity.

Results from previous studies remain also contradictory regarding the influence of maltreatment on emotion regulation. Several studies highlighted a link between maltreatment experiences in childhood and lower emotion recognition or mentalizing abilities whereas others found a link between maltreatment and higher emotion regulation abilities (Brüne et al., 2016; Robin et al., 2022; Schuder & Lyons-Ruth, 2004). However, few studies investigated connections between the nature of maltreatment experiences (abuse versus neglect), the dysfunctional parental bonding type (controlling environment versus low care environment) and emotional awareness. In our study we found a distinct impact on emotional awareness from the two types of dysfunctional parental bonding. A lower level of maternal care was correlated to higher sensitivity to other’s emotions whereas higher maternal control was associated to lower levels of emotional awareness of self and others. Those results are consistent with a previous study conducted by Robin et al. (2022) which highlighted a correlation between parental bonding characterized by a deficit of relational stimuli (neglect/withdrawal environment) and hypersensitivity to facial emotional recognition, whereas dysfunctional parental bonding characterized by excess of relational stimuli (abuse and overcontrolling environment) was correlated to lower accuracy of facial emotional recognition in BPD. In the light of attachment theories, Janczak assumes that in the presence of a threatening or overcontrolling caregiver, adolescents might block identification of other’s mental state, while in the presence of a frustrating or self-absorbed caregiver, the strategy used by adolescents with BPD could involve an increased motivation and sensitivity to guess the caregiver's mental state (Jańczak, 2018). Furthermore, previous findings highlighted a link between maternal withdrawal over the first eight years of life and child caregiving attitude. Caregiving attitude for children have implied hypersensitivity to emotional stimuli in order to protect caregivers in a dynamic of reversed roles (Schuder & Lyons-Ruth, 2004). Conversely, a controlling parenting style could invade the child’s privacy and autonomy, and lead them to protect themselves from external stimuli, instead of looking after them (Robin et al., 2022). These results reinforce these previous findings and Bowlby’s clinical observations of distinct effects of adversity types on children’s development, including the development of hyper-vigilance to others in a context of parental relational withdrawal (Bowlby, 1988). And in case of BPD, it has been already demonstrated that different types of maltreatment experiences often co-occur with each other (Dong et al., 2003), consequently a patient with BPD may also alternatively decrease or enhance his emotional awareness depending on the social situation.

Consistent with previous data, we found a higher use of immature and neurotic defense mechanisms among patients with BPD compared to HC subjects (Zanarini et al., 2009). Moreover, we measured that the immature defense mechanisms mitigated the deleterious effect of adversity on self-awareness. The result of a positive correlation between immature defense mechanisms and self-emotional awareness in BPD may appear surprising because immature defense mechanisms preferentially used by BPD patients involve self and others distorted images (such as splitting or projective identification), which could reflect individual disconnection from their emotions. To our knowledge, no study has already explored the links between adversity, defense mechanisms and emotional awareness in BPD. Only two studies have tested the links between defense mechanisms and alexithymia or mentalization: they observed a negative effect of defense mechanisms on alexithymia and on reflective functions in dysthymic or depressed patients respectively (Tanzilli et al., 2021; Wise et al., 2010). Defense mechanisms correspond to the prioritized means for individuals to deal with emotions and thoughts that cause distress feelings, in order to survive. According to Kernberg (Kernberg & Adamov, 1989), defense mechanisms used by patients with BPD, even immature, allow for individuals to achieve the best possible equilibrium by protecting them from losing contact with reality and experiencing lack of differentiation from others. The LEAS involves identifying the emotions elicited in a social situation, but not more complex elements to be integrated from these emotions, such as the thoughts, motivations and intentions of others defining their context. Our results raise the hypothesis that in a context of adversity, defense mechanisms allow to function in a degraded mode that would preserves awareness of emotions, at the cost of distorted identification of contextual mental states. For example, splitting is at the basis of Manichean way of thinking characterizing borderline cognitions (Linehan, 1993). It is a binary (black-and-white) way of representing the world, including a lesser degree of complexity. These results echo John Briere's ‘trauma of the self’ model, that describes the affective, cognitive and behavioral dysfunctions of psycho-traumatized children, and the way in which the transition to ‘survival mode’ alters their reflexive functions (Briere, 2002). Moreover, our supplementary finding of immature defense mechanisms mitigating the negative effect of adversity on self-awareness reinforce this suggestion of a protective effect on emotion perception, in that immature defense would appear when there is a need to counterbalance effects of maltreatment experiences and regulate emotions to maintain their level of functioning with less available resources. These results situates both emotional awareness and defense mechanisms in their adaptive function in the face of adversity (Smith et al., 2023), and suggest that defense mechanisms have a key role in maintaining a normal level of emotional awareness in these situations.

Although the literature on the links between adversity, emotional regulation and borderline personality disorder is still lacking, our study's finding of correlations between these dimensions without any alteration in the level of emotional awareness of these patients (compared with controls) is, in our view, to be seen in both a traumatic and a developmental dimension. Our results, added to those of the adult literature, suggest that traumatic alterations of emotional awareness may be progressive, and that defense mechanisms may play an adaptive role, including in the period before the deficit becomes visible. Defense mechanisms seem to enable emotional and relational functioning to be maintained, but on a simplified basis (manichaean thinking and behaviors, cleavage, etc.). Taken together, these arguments strengthen the need for caution in diagnosing borderline personality disorder before adulthood (Adshead et al., 2012). Indeed, the evidence for the impact of trauma in borderline psychopathological mechanisms calls for the promotion of holistic management of the disorder, integrating adolescent protection and early trauma-informed care, which reduces the frequency of the disorder in adulthood and its functional prognosis (Hopper et al., 2010; Robin et al., 2023). Adolescents in this study were diagnosed with borderline personality disorder according to DSM criteria, guaranteeing to this study solid inter-rater validity. But given that a diagnosis at age 15 is only likely to be made in 25% of cases at age 17, the predictive validity constitutes the main challenge of the diagnosis (Bernstein et al., 1993; Levy et al., 1999), and our results provide psychopathological insight suggesting that it would be more prudent in these cases to evoke terms such as ‘borderline crisis in adolescence' (Robin, 2011) rather than labelling it as a personality disorder. The notion of crisis instead of personality disorder allows us to identify borderline symptoms without determining a risk of harmful long-term prognosis. Moreover, the term crisis clearly situates defense mechanisms in their primary adaptive function in a context of deteriorated processing. It also points more easily to the major role to be given to therapeutics, which show many possibilities, especially at this transitional age, and which can thus directly target emotional awareness (Smith et al., 2024).

Some limitations must be considered when evaluating the results of our study. First, the sample size would require confirmation of these results in a larger group of borderline adolescents. Because of this sample size, we were unable to use CTQ sub-scales that differentiate types of abuse (physical, sexual and emotional) and neglect (physical and emotional). Studies assessing the respective impact of these different types of abuse and neglect on emotional awareness should be conducted to better understand in which way adversity events affect or not emotional awareness. Furthermore, the absence of a clinical control group questions the specificity of our results on the borderline dimension, and requires confirmation on larger samples including at least one group of patients with depression (the most significant BPD comorbidity). On the other hand, the effect of adversity on emotion regulation is probably not specific to the various diagnoses, as shown by the study by Beals et al. (2024), which has shown that impaired emotional awareness is associated with childhood maltreatment exposure and positive symptoms in schizophrenia. Finally, the validity of measuring parent–child bonding, and maltreatment events in childhood through subjective assessments may be questioned because of potential memory bias. Although the use of the PBI and CTQ scales is common in these populations, future research should focus on the use of both objective and subjective measures to assess these variables and detect potential discrepancies.

To conclude, this first study exploring levels of emotional awareness in adolescents with BPD tempers the assumption of a deficit in BPD emotional awareness, and reinforce previous findings of distinct effects of adversity types on children’s affective and perceptive development. Moreover, it suggests that defense mechanisms have a core regulation function of adversity effects on emotional processing, that could allow impacted adolescents to maintain their normal level of emotional awareness for a period of time.
